rote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> =C2=A0I put my NEAT-based experimental setup online, her=
e : http://www.marmakoide.org/download/research/blackbolt-neat-1.0.zip
> Th=
e archive is mostly self-contained, you Python to compile the thing. Docume=
ntation included in the package. It's a usage of NEAT, not verbatim HyperNE=
AT : I use input space to compute thickness of beams of a mechanical struct=
ure, not the weight for a neuron network. But the principle is the same, NE=
AT algorithm and CPPN.=C2=A0Definitely=C2=A0compile on Unix-ish systems, sh=
ould compile on Windows but not tested that. Call mothership if you need su=
pport, we're ready ^^
> 
> Cheers,
> Alex

> 
> Alex,
> If an individual maps to a=
 point evaluation of the design space, and the local jacobian of the fitnes=
s landscape is such that an added local gradient based sub-optimization tas=
k follows a trajectory resulting in an improved fitness associated w/ an up=
dated individual, would that satisfy the classification requirements associ=
ated w/ "implicit evolved embryogeny"? Also, would you consider uploading y=
our updated version of Hyperneat used in your study to the group file repos=
itory?
> Thanks,
> Andy
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Alexandre Devert =
<marmakoide@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> > =C3=82=C2=A0 I'm not 100% sure to get =
the whole meaning of your question, so I might answer a bit off-target ^^
>=
 > 
> > =C3=82=C2=A0 In that paragraph about the taxonomy (end of page 4), =
I mention "local information". It's not a gradient, as in "gradient based o=
ptimization", that is, a clue on the local geometry of the objective functi=
on. By "local information", I mean, *any* kind of local feedback of the beh=
avior of the phenotype. If we optimize a plane wing, it could be, say, the =
local air pressure. If we optimize a heat exchanger, it would be local heat=
h flux. If we optimize a water pipe network, it would the local water flux =
and pressure.
> > 
> > 
> > =C3=82=C2=A0Then, does this local information f=
eeback turns "external non-evolved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embry=
ogeny" ? It's quite a fuzzy territory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode =
the genotype as a transformation of an initial phenotype to a final one. Yo=
u have many many ways to do this, and you can have genotype as a very flexi=
ble transformation (many many development steps, each doing small changes i=
n all possible ways) or a very inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transf=
ormation step). So between "external non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit =
evolved embryogeny", I believe there is a whole gradient of possibilities r=
ather than a sharp border between the two. Actually, to have a trully "impl=
icit evolved embryogeny", it would unbounded development. But in practice, =
allowing a few steps of development brings a lot of flexibility for a genot=
ype, so it's a rethoritical remark.
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > 
> > Alex
> > 
> >=

n fully comfortable with the spatial transformation constraint assumption.
